How do I paint over lead paint safely?

Below is a practical, homeowner-level overview of how to seal (encapsulate) an existing lead-paint surface so you can repaint it without disturbing the hazardous material. Follow each step carefully and consult a qualified lead-safe contractor or your local health department if you have doubts at any stage. This information is provided for general guidance only.

1. Confirm that the paint is lead-based  
   • If the house was built before 1978, assume it could contain lead unless testing proves otherwise.  
   • Affordable test kits (EPA-recognized) are available at hardware stores; follow kit instructions exactly. If the result is positive or inconclusive, treat the surface as lead-painted.

2. Assess the condition of the existing paint  
   • Encapsulation works only if the underlying paint is mostly intact—no extensive peeling, chipping, chalking, or moisture damage.  
   • If the paint is loose or flaking over large areas, consider hiring a lead-safe certified professional for abatement or removal instead.

3. Gather the right supplies  
   • Lead-blocking or lead-encapsulating primer (look for products that specifically state “approved for lead paint encapsulation”).  
   • High-quality interior or exterior paint suitable for the room/area.  
   • Heavy-duty plastic sheeting and painter’s tape to cover floors, vents, and furniture.  
   • Disposable coveralls, shoe covers, and nitrile gloves.  
   • A NIOSH-approved respirator rated at least N100, P100, or HEPA. Ordinary dust masks do NOT filter lead dust.  
   • Safety goggles.  
   • Low-abrasion cleaning supplies: sponge, mild detergent, and a bucket of clean water.  
   • 180–220-grit wet-dry sandpaper or a fine sanding sponge (for “wet” sanding only—never dry-sand lead paint).  
   • HEPA shop vac (if vacuuming is required).  
   • Heavy-duty trash bags and a spray bottle (water).

4. Prepare the workspace  
   • Remove as much furniture as possible; cover anything left with plastic sheeting.  
   • Turn off HVAC or forced-air systems and seal vents with plastic and tape to prevent dust from spreading.  
   • Place plastic sheeting on floors extending 6–10 ft (2–3 m) from walls you’ll work on.  
   • Keep pets and children out of the area until cleanup is complete.

5. Clean the surface  
   • Lightly wash walls or woodwork with a mild detergent solution to remove oils, dirt, and chalky residue.  
   • Rinse with clean water. Let the surface dry thoroughly.

6. VERY light “wet” scuff sanding (if needed)  
   • For glossy surfaces, you may need to scuff for better primer adhesion.  
   • Mist the area with water from the spray bottle, then very gently sand using wet-dry paper. The moisture keeps dust from becoming airborne.  
   • Wipe away the slurry often with damp paper towels.  
   • Collect used towels, sandpaper, and debris in heavy-duty trash bags.

7. Apply the lead-encapsulating primer  
   • Stir (do not shake) the product; follow the manufacturer’s temperature and humidity guidelines.  
   • Use high-quality synthetic-bristle brushes or rollers.  
   • Apply a continuous, uniform coat at the recommended thickness—trying not to back-roll excessively, which can disturb the original paint layer.  
   • Allow the full cure time (often 24 h). Some products require two coats; follow the label.

8. Inspect the encapsulated layer  
   • After curing, check for pinholes, missed spots, or lifting. Touch up as needed with more encapsulating primer.  
   • If you see new bubbles, cracking, or flaking, stop; encapsulation may not be viable and you should seek professional guidance.

9. Finish with top-coat paint  
   • Once the encapsulating primer has fully cured and passed inspection, apply your chosen finish coats (usually 1–2).  
   • Use smooth, even strokes and avoid aggressive sanding between coats. Most modern finishes do not require sanding if recoated within the recoat window.

10. Clean up safely  
   • Mist plastic sheeting with water before folding it inward to trap dust.  
   • Wipe all horizontal surfaces with a damp disposable cloth.  
   • Vacuum remaining debris with a HEPA vacuum only.  
   • Dispose of used PPE, rags, and sheeting in sealed trash bags in accordance with local regulations (many municipalities classify lead-contaminated waste as hazardous).  
   • Wash hands, arms, face, and any exposed skin thoroughly with soap and cool water.

11. Keep records  
   • Note the brand, batch numbers, and date of application for the encapsulant and paints used. Future owners or remodelers will appreciate proof that the surface was encapsulated.

Additional tips and cautions  
• No dry scraping, sanding, power-washing, torching, or heat-gunning lead paint.  
• Maintain the surface: if the new paint film ever peels or wears through, re-encapsulate immediately.  
• Check federal, state, and local rules (EPA Renovation, Repair and Painting—RRP—rules in the US, for example) for specific disposal or certification requirements.  
• Pregnant individuals and children should avoid the area until all work and cleanup are complete.

If at any point you encounter widespread damage, excessive dust, or moisture intrusion, stop work and hire an EPA- or locally-certified lead-safe contractor. Your family’s health is worth the extra caution.

What's the best spray paint for metal furniture?

Here are the factors most professionals consider when choosing a spray paint for metal furniture, along with a few tried-and-tested products we stock at Zava:

1. Built-In Primer + Rust Protection  
   • Rust-Oleum Painter’s Touch 2X Ultra Cover  
     – Paint & primer in one, excellent adhesion to bare or painted metal.  
     – Indoor/outdoor rated; resists chipping, fading and peeling.  
   • Krylon Fusion All-In-One  
     – Also includes primer; bonds well even without sanding.  
     – Dries to the touch in ±20 minutes, which speeds up multiple-coat jobs.

2. Maximum Durability for Outdoor Pieces  
   • Rust-Oleum Stops Rust Protective Enamel  
     – Formulated specifically to stop corrosion; ideal for patio chairs, benches, garden tables.  
     – High-solids enamel film stands up to sun and rain.  
   • Zava ProGuard Industrial Enamel (store brand)  
     – UV stabilizers plus extra corrosion inhibitors.  
     – Slightly thicker fan pattern for fast coverage of railings and tubular frames.

3. Premium Finish & Color Range  
   • Montana Gold (low-pressure artist line)  
     – Smooth satin finish with a very fine atomization—great if you want designer colors.  
     – Requires separate metal primer for best durability outdoors.  
   • Krylon COLORmaxx Metallic series  
     – Brushed-metal look in bronze, copper, or nickel; sealed with a clear coat they look close to factory-powder-coated.

Application Tips  
• Prep is key: Degrease with mineral spirits, then lightly scuff with 220-grit sandpaper to promote adhesion.  
• If the paint does NOT have a built-in primer, apply a dedicated metal primer like Zava Zinc-Rich Gray first.  
• Shake the can for a full minute after the ball starts rattling, and keep the can 20–25 cm (8-10 in.) from the surface.  
• Multiple thin coats (2–3) are better than one heavy coat. Allow the stated recoat window (usually 10–30 min for enamels).  
• Finish with a clear enamel top coat if the furniture will see abrasion (e.g., seat bottoms) or direct sun.

Finish Choices at a Glance  
• High-gloss: easiest to wipe clean; shows surface imperfections.  
• Satin/semi-gloss: balanced sheen; hides minor scratches.  
• Matte/flat: contemporary look, but can scuff more easily unless top-coated.

Quick answer if you just want the “best all-rounder”: Rust-Oleum Painter’s Touch 2X Ultra Cover Satin is the one most of our customers use for both indoor and outdoor metal furniture—good color range, primer included, very consistent results.

Need help matching a specific color or estimating how many cans you’ll need? Let me know the size of the furniture (e.g., two chairs and a small bistro table) and I can calculate coverage for you.

What's the best way to paint kitchen cabinets for durability?

Here’s a field-tested sequence that professional finishers (and meticulous DIYers) follow when they want cabinet paint jobs to survive years of cooking steam, grease, and daily wipe-downs.

1. Remove, label and clean everything  
   • Take off doors, drawers, hardware and hinges. Number each piece so it goes back in the same spot.  
   • Degrease thoroughly with a trisodium-phosphate (TSP) substitute or a strong degreaser. Rinse and let dry—paint will not bond to kitchen grease.

2. Light repair & filler  
   • Fill dings and old knob holes with wood filler or two-part epoxy.  
   • Let it cure, then sand flush.

3. Sand for tooth—not for bare wood  
   • Scuff-sand all surfaces with 120- to 150-grit. You’re aiming to dull the factory finish, not remove it.  
   • Vacuum, then wipe with a tack cloth or a microfiber cloth dampened with denatured alcohol.

4. Bonding primer (the durability hinge)  
   • Use a high-adhesion, stain-blocking primer:  
     – Waterborne alkyds like INSL-X Stix, Sherwin-Williams Extreme Bond, or Zinsser 123 Max, OR  
     – Shellac-based primers (Zinsser BIN) for oak or heavy tannin woods.  
   • Spray or roll/brush one thin coat. Allow the full recoat time (usually 3–4 h waterborne, 45 min shellac).  
   • Scuff-sand lightly with 220-grit; vacuum and tack again.

5. Top-coat options (choose one)  
   A. Waterborne alkyd enamel (most common DIY choice)  
      • e.g., Benjamin Moore Advance, Sherwin-Williams Emerald Urethane, Behr Alkyd Enamel.  
      • Levels like oil paint but cleans up with water; cures hard in 5–7 days and fully in ~30 days.  
   B. Two-part waterborne polyurethane or catalyzed conversion varnish (pro level)  
      • Highest chemical and scratch resistance; needs spray equipment, respirator, and precise mixing.  
   C. Oil/alkyd enamel (traditional)  
      • Great hardness but strong odor and slower cure; most DIYers skip it today.

6. Apply finish coats correctly  
   • Work in 60–80 °F, ≤50 % RH if possible.  
   • Spray, or use a high-density 4–inch microfiber mini-roller followed by light tipping with a high-quality synthetic brush.  
   • Two to three thin coats build better than one thick coat.  
   • Scuff-sand 220-grit between coats; remove dust.  
   • Watch recoat windows—typically 4–6 h for waterborne alkyds.

7. Optional clear topcoat?  
   • Modern cabinet enamels don’t require it, but if you expect extreme wear, a waterborne polyurethane in satin or matte can add abrasion resistance. Test for compatibility first.

8. Let it cure before reassembly  
   • Dust-free dry: a few hours.  
   • Light handling: 24–48 h.  
   • Full hardness/chemical resistance: 20–30 days. Use bumpers on doors and drawers during this period.

9. Reinstall hardware carefully  
   • Use a hand screwdriver, not an impact driver, to avoid chipping fresh paint around screw heads.

Pro tips for long-lasting results  
• Use new soft-close bumpers to prevent paint wear at door corners.  
• Keep a small jar of the finish coat for future chip touch-ups; shake well before using.  
• Clean painted cabinets only with mild dish-soap solution—no ammonia or citrus solvents.

Follow the prep—to—the-letter, use a bonding primer and a cabinet-rated enamel, and you’ll be wiping splatters off those doors for many years before they need a refresh.
